content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Just no, for the first few hours you do get a slight buzz, and it really does interest me but, after these hours the game just stops. This seriously disappointed me as i soon realize what you need to get a full immersive action: a membership of 3, 6 or 12 months, other guns as (the one you are given is only allowed to be used on a few animals), scopes for the guns and ammunition these all have a sizable price tag and i haven't even mentioned clothes and other addons to make the hunting easier. this may sound like a rant, and it probably is, but it is just annoying that they claim to be a free to play(by definition, a game which gives players access to a significant portion of their content without paying) which is clearly not fufliled in this supposedly free to play game and the developers should be quite ashamed in portraying it to be so (reading through the features they have given, there is no mention of only being able to shoot one animal and only limited to one park for guest).on the other hand if you are willing to pay on the region of $40 to have enjoyable experience then i am sure you will have a great experience, but withn the next few months or maybe a year you will have to pay another $20 or more to kepp you going on the bare minimum or to get the next urgrade, gun or membership.back on to those who do not want to pay, like me, you should download this game; just to see if you like it because it is your decision which is the ultimate decider, but do not come into this game thinking you will get a sizeable portion of content as you will be severly disappionted. This is a good game in theory and with the willing to pay constant money, but it underacheives what is expected of an average F2P.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
Day one::I was roaming and couldn't find a single animal for nearly an entire hour. I found some tracks and went in a full circle, tracking multiple rabbits and deer. Not a single animal was found.Day two: :I tracked some feral hogs down. While trying to noscope them, they rammed me. My bloodied and bruised rolled down a hill while I was injured. That was fun.Day three: :I spotted a rock. I named him Jim. Jim was a floating rock. He could fly away to the stars if he wanted to. But he didn't want to.Day four: :I found three rabbits - All of which fled like♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ They didn't even challenge my noscoping capabilities. One of them even strolled right infront of me as I was writing this down. What a prick.Day five: :I located several coyotes. I channeled my inner Sonic and ran like hell, if hell had a moped. I then assumed I would never catch anything without being injured and started shooting the butterflies. They were even harder to shoot. I concluded that the trees, grass and rocks would be my safest hunting targets for the next week or so. I could simply live off their profitable and highly nutritious entrails.Day six: :I found a flock of pheasents. Yes. This will be my one and only chance.. Steady.. Steady.. FI- Wait, I can't shoot pheasents..? Well, I better go live off of Jim and his family again.Day seven: :I decided to screw the intention of this game and simply enjoy the scenic views, the beautiful colors, the delicious deer right infront of m- SHOOT IT NOW.The only thing I wanted to shoot after playing this game was myself.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												I never review game, but I feel like I have to do it on this one, seeing all the bad reviews it is getting, mostly because of the "Free to play" tag. First, if you want this game to be fun, the "Free to play" tag does not apply. The free part is only useful to make sure you can run the game and get a glimpse of what it is.I started playing this game a while ago from its web page (around 130hrs) and continued on Steam since I got Windows 10. I spent around 60$ so far and I'm well equipped to hunt everything in every reserve, or almost; my friend have bought different guns/deployable items than I did, so we didn't "double buy" anything and we can do 99% of missions and hunt ducks and geeses comfortably, which are the most expensive to hunt. Anyway, lots of fun to hunt in all the reserves with friends or strangers or even alone. Great variety of species, good graphics, competitions and leaderboards to get the adrenaline up when you think this is the big buck you were waiting for!I think you have to consider it like a normal game you usually pay between 40$ to 60$ (bundles of several months of  membership and additional guns and stuff available, or buy points to get what you want separatly) and you will have lots of hours of good hunting. After that, when you membership ends, you choose to renew it for another 3 months (3-4$/month) or not, but if you really like hunting games, I bet you will!In the end, if money is really an issue, this game is not for you

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												The Hunter is a hunting simulator where your goal is to simply collect the highest scoring animal (in short).It features a wide range of animals to hunt from small game to big game in different environments.This combined with new daily competitions to win trophies and in-game cash creates a fun and non-repetitive experience.It is also being constantly updated with new gear, animals and places to hunt at, and if you don't like playing alone there's also multiplayer. Players can enter different teams in a multiplayer game and compete with eachother.The graphics are also outstanding and it's a really immersive experience and definitely the best hunting simulator to date.I've been playing this since early 2012 and will keep playing for years i'm sure.If I had to give it a grade it would be around 95/100, there's no perfect 100/100 game, every game has its flaws, no matter how small they may be. But in this genre you won't find a better game than The Hunter.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												This game is really fun considering it is Free-to-play, the one issue everyone has is that you cannot hunt any animal without a license apart from the Mule Deer. You can hunt rabbits but you don't have a weapon at the start that you are allowed to use on them. Now don't get me wrong, sure their tactic with the buying of weapons, licenses, gear is a bit out there, since I believe they should allow you to put in game time to be able to purchase said things but they dont. What I would say is, if you play it a lot like I do recently, Just get the 10 dollar for 3 months and you can shoot any animal that you can shoot with the .243 rifle you get automatically for playing the game. You will get your money's worth even if you play twice a week or even once a week.Gameplay: 9 - Really nice, love the animations and the way you can track and kill your prey.Sound: 8 - It is really nice sound, mostly just nature but it still relaxes you if you are into that thing.Graphics: 8 - The game does feature nice graphics but also bad, I constantly notice my hand looks wooden at times.Story: Not Applicable

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												I played this hunting simulator for maybe half an hour? Something like that. Still I can say the f2p version is a strong canditate for the "Walking Simulator 2014" award. Or more like crawling slowly simulator as walking and running will scare the wildlife away. So first of all, it's free to play. Kinda. You can only use the default weapon (rest you need to buy with real money) and gear. You can only create single player matches without paying a subscription of some sort. You can also hunt only some certain type of deers. You need to buy licenses for the rest of the animals. When I wandered around the forest, I found tracks of many animals and my GPS thingy told me their direction.Even though I didn't have the required licenses to hunt pheasants, I still tried to take a shot at it (as I was unable to locate the only animal I'm allowed to hunt). When I pulled the trigger, my character dropped his aim and an info box appeared on top of the screen saying that I need to buy a license in order to fire my rifle towards animals. Lame.


theHunter 
A Screenshot of theHunter
By: Miggoh




The maps are really big and graphically the game looks pretty good and the draw distance is great (which I guess is important in a game like this). It's a bit too realistic game for me though. I don'y feel like sitting in a hunting lodge for five hours, just to have a chance to shoot a deer.

When I wandered around the forest, I found tracks of many animals and my GPS thingy told me their direction.Even though I didn't have the required licenses to hunt pheasants, I still tried to take a shot at it (as I was unable to locate the only animal I'm allowed to hunt). When I pulled the trigger, my character dropped his aim and an info box appeared on top of the screen saying that I need to buy a license in order to fire my rifle towards animals. Lame.


theHunter 
A Screenshot of theHunter
By: Miggoh




The maps are really big and graphically the game looks pretty good and the draw distance is great (which I guess is important in a game like this). It's a bit too realistic game for me though. I don'y feel like sitting in a hunting lodge for five hours, just to have a chance to shoot a deer.

number of helpful: 58 of 113 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												I believe this game is for a certain type of player. First if you are impatient this game is not for you. If you crave constant action then you probably won't like this. If you don't want to spend any money then this is not for you. If you like to hunt, enjoy the reward of patiently stalking and killing something, have some money to spend; then you will probably like this.I'll comment first about the gameplay then about the pricing of the "free to play" in the second/third paragraph.The game has a slower pace to it, I'll give an example of a typical hunt for me. I spawn at a lodge and load up my equipment in my inventory; I'm hunting whitetail and maybe turkey today so I want my shotgun for versatility and bow for stealth, I could take my .243 rifle but I prefer the shotgun. It's early in the morning and I can see the misty dew settling on the grass plains. The air feels fresh as I slowly wander about looking for my sign. A red tracker mark over some footprints point me in the way of a deer and I walk after it. I want to rush and sprint but I must be patient lest I spook it away. Droppings indicate to me how far it might be, more footprints help me close in on it when I hear the grunt of a buck. I crouch down and sit. I could stalk it down, but I'd rather the deer come to me. I pull out my deer call and mimic the sound of a doe to the open air. A call from the buck responds in kind. The bucks grunts get louder and louder, I know which way he's coming from but there is too much brush in the way. I lay down amongst some grass to make my profile even smaller and wait for him to reveal himself. At last I spot him standing tall and he calls out for the doe in my trap. He is still too far out so I maneuver onto a small hill for a better vantage while he gently and slowly walks in. I watch him closely and load a shell of buckshot into my shotgun, he suspects nothing. He has a decent set of antlers, nothing special, but he carries himself as a king. Still, I know my role as assassin well and wait for him to close in  enough to see the grain of his antlers. Finally he stops before me and raises his head high as I hold my breath to steady the shot. Silence tells him nothing until a cacophonous blast reverberates through the air and scares away any nearby animals from the king as he falls to his knees and lands his face in the dirt. I pull out my huntermate, snap a trophy shot, and claim my work. Walking away I eject the spent shell and load another, there's plenty out there yet on the reserve today. The game looks pretty good and I can tell they put quite a bit of work into the environment. There are a few bugs that happen in multiplayer but otherwise the game itself is very good.Now for the reveal of the abnormal market. Since this appears to be a niche game, they have decided to get it paid for in a way, I think, most steam gamers aren't accustomed to. The free-to-play isn't, its more of a demo really. When you first start out you can only hunt mule dear and rabbit with your one .243 rifle, and shooting rabbit with your rifle will give you disqualifying kills. If you want to hunt everything then you can get, at minimum, a 10$ membership which is good for 3 months. On top of that you'll want calls, other weapons, equipment, which all cost real money. To further the currency explaination: The game has paid for currency (em$) and earned currency (gm$). Em$ is a cent to cent ratio, 100em$ is $1.00. Almost every weapon is 4-6 dollars, yeah, I know. Each call is over a dollar, clothes costs a few bucks (don't buy individually, get bundles), stands, blinds, other items are all going to be 4 dollars or so. In other words, you can easily spend more than a triple-A $60 title. In other words, if you put money down, spend smart (research stuff) and make sure you're getting what you want.Gm$ are earned by doing missions and are terribly underutilized and overpriced in the store. I do enjoy doing the missions, a little extra goal and challenge to a hunt, not too hard to accomplish. With gm$ you can buy one single shot shotgun for 6200 (I have it, I like it) otherwise you can get sprays to attract animals or bait and that is pretty much it. You would think at least some clothing but nope. You can get animal licenses individually with gm$ but its priced so high for a beginner its not worth it (1800 gm$ for 1 day of turkey hunting). I sort of understand why everything is so expensive compared to other games but I don't agree with it.A little more about my experience that may be helpful. I hunted with a friend who picked up items so I didn't have to get everything, he got a bunch of mallard gear, I got a bunch of geese gear. I only hunt with the .243 rifle (given for free) which is good for most deer and coyote and fox. A 12 gauge shotgun, which can shoot anything except birds with slugs and birdshot can shoot those (you get three kinds of shells and it replenishes for every trip). So yes, with one shotgun you can shoot any animal in the game, given somewhat limited range. Finally a compound bow which is great for stealth and when you have multiple animals coming as it won't scatter them like a gun. So my method is very up close and personal usually but only took the purchase of the bow; the pump-action shotgun came with a membership bundle. If you want to hunt big game with a rifle get something up in the .300 caliber range and you're good to go.So as a result: Good game for patient gamers who have decent income. Bad game for someone looking for an actual free-to-play game like War Thunder or LoL and/or doesn't like somewhat realistic hunting. Of course you can always try it out yourself. Do the tutorials when you start it up (Hunt Now -> Tutorials) Also read up on the wiki (thehunterwiki.com) has a lot of useful information. If you do decide to get into the game and put down money. I recommend one of the membership bundles, you get a lot more than getting it individually.If this review isn't helpful please comment why and I'll do my best to improve it with what you need to know.

number of helpful: 47 of 92 people (51%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Note this is not a free 2 play game and the free 2 play content is limited in scope to the point where it is just a demo. This game is a game that takes time and some investment to enjoy, first off I suggest buying a membership after trying the game, this will allow you to hunt all game. I have a Trailrunner (1 year) membership, this gives you a few guns some calls and a membership, also the membership gives you 3 replenishing boxes of ammo after every hunt, so you hunt use it all quit start a new hunt and it will be available again. I also bought every call, and some set up bundles, but that was after around 40 hours in the game. The graphics are great and immerse you into these beautiful reserves. The tracking and spotting of animals is excellent. Animals have a nice variety in size and antlers. There also rare coloration differences and for some deer non typical antlers. There are dogs for waterfowl and they are a nice premium item. There is also bow hunting which involves stalking and getting up close to your prey, an intense and fun experience.Ok enough rambling, basically this game, is more like an iracing you need to narrow what you want to hunt or do or be prepared to spend more than what an average game costs. More on hunting on a budget, pick a style not species say bow hunting, competition hunting, waterfowl, big game etc. Then buy some the items that help you hunt in that style, for bow hunting maybe some camo and an upgraded bow, competition, the calls can be key, waterfowl a blind and decoys, big game calls and a nice rifle. So it can be played on a budget but to be the best at hunting everything can get expensive, now the setups mentioned above can be had for around $20 - $30 a piece and this is on the high end. This is not a free to play game but a hardcore hunting simulation, but if you find what you want to hunt through watching videos or trying to hunt them you can immerse yourself even on a budget.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												The only hunting simulator worth playing out there at the moment!The Hunter couples gorgeous graphics and immersive sound design to create vast environments that feel real when you step into them, something that other hunting games out there just don’t replicate. Recent hunting games have been shoe-horning you down corridors while Ibex and Lions jump out onto your shotgun barrel. The Hunter gives you the opportunity to experience the journey, a complete hunting scenario: Listening out for calls, tracking, and observation, not just constantly providing a slurry of beautiful beasts to bludgeon.I believe the game suffers when informing new comers. I’d recommend checking out the wiki before jumping in as there are some rules for Guest players who haven’t purchased a membership regarding what you can hunt and where. I have all confidence in the Dev team though! They are constantly active and seem to value and utilise feedback. New content is always on the horizon whether it is new gear, weapons, species or reserves to hunt. The game also boasts a strong community to hunt alongside or against in an interesting array of hunting challenges.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												The only hunting simulator worth playing out there at the moment!The Hunter couples gorgeous graphics and immersive sound design to create vast environments that feel real when you step into them, something that other hunting games out there just don’t replicate. Recent hunting games have been shoe-horning you down corridors while Ibex and Lions jump out onto your shotgun barrel. The Hunter gives you the opportunity to experience the journey, a complete hunting scenario: Listening out for calls, tracking, and observation, not just constantly providing a slurry of beautiful beasts to bludgeon.I believe the game suffers when informing new comers. I’d recommend checking out the wiki before jumping in as there are some rules for Guest players who haven’t purchased a membership regarding what you can hunt and where. I have all confidence in the Dev team though! They are constantly active and seem to value and utilise feedback. New content is always on the horizon whether it is new gear, weapons, species or reserves to hunt. The game also boasts a strong community to hunt alongside or against in an interesting array of hunting challenges.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
												Great game... if you're alright hunting ONLY mule deer, cottontail and european rabbits; the latter two of which require specific guns/ammo you do not begin with in the free game.Runs well on my crappy little laptop and installed fairly quickly.As everyone has said - it's called a "free" game in the same way an incomplete game that requires paid DLC to run properly could be.Expect to spend a good few hours hunting and your first few "successful" hunts to give you nothing as you'll spend more time than allocated trying to find the damn thing.As I said, have spent many hours on this game, and am personally /alright/ with hunting mules, but if you're wanting a game with variety where you don't get frustrated by ending up finding a track to an animal you can't hunt in the end then this isn't the game for you.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												So, I'm back, and this time, an in-depth (not really) review of thehunter. So, yes I know, microtransactions suck, but even if you pay the $15.00 fee for a license(3 months, I believe), you WILL enjoy this game. I happen to find the game really fun. I have decided to buy the $50.00 membership (12 months). The $15.00 and both, the $50.00 plan, come with weapons. The $15.00 comes with a little bit of stuff, but not a load. The $50.00 gives you a bow, two pistols, two shotguns, and two rifles (I may be wrong about that). They both, of course give you a license to hunt all animals and unlimited basic ammo. So if you really don't like the idea of the game, then maybe this will help you face the microtransactions, if you want to play, of course. Thanks for reading this review, this is my opinion of the game, I enjoy playing it, and have collected this informaton since the last time I wrote a review on this game.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												I played the Hunter well before it went to Steam and thoroughly enjoyed the game, even more so competitively hunting against other players I knew in multiplayer.  So many of the Steam reviews revolve around two themes:  this games isn't F2P, and it doesn't deliver instant gratification.There is no such thing as a free lunch.  I wonder how many of the negative reviewers have purchased premium time in WoT, WoW, AW, or War Thunder?  Or have spent $$$ on the Lowe in WoT?  Maybe a premium ship in WoW?  Of course you should feel entitled that they conform their payment model to other games, that bare very little simularity to what they have created. /sarcasm  This isn't an arcade game like a Cabellas special, it actually makes you have patience and some skill.  I think they know that the masses aren't going to find this title appealing, that it won't be Far Cry Primal.  If you want to participate in something unique, you have to pay the entrance fee.  The best part is that they have constantly expanded the content and listened to community feedback.  And when you start looking at the content, you start seeing that you don't need every piece of it to have fun.  You could hunt almost any animal in any reserve with a 12 gauge pump.  I personally like the classic muzzle loader.  I have a few guns and a bow, but they compliment what I like to hunt, as does my gear.  I don't have to have or expect all of the content.  The most important part is that license. $35 gets you 12 months to hunt any species.  That's not $14/month for premium time in some other games.  I think people are conveniently ignoring that they can selectively buy the content and experience they want.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												This game has the biggest split in reviews I've seen.There's a huge paywall to really get into the game but that wall typically only comes if you like it enough to spend money on it. The free to play experience is fine to demo the game out plus signing up for an account nets you a three day membership. You won't get the full experience but you'll be able to preview the meat of the gameplay, which is what this game is all about.If you don't have a lot of free time there is no gameplay whatsoever. However, if you're patient enough to just sit back and immerse yourself for a while with the occasional distraction, you'll find the deepest hunting game out there. It's pretty much just like real hunting. You walk to a good spot or find and track signs of an animal. Then you carefully set up a shot and shoot it. There's a thrill to findind a big buck, grizzly bear, or a huge flock of fowl coming your way. Shooting it is a challenge, and pulling off a clean kill is rewarding. Adding it to your ever-growing list of kills and trophy-shots is merely the aftertaste of a good hunt.As for the pay to play element, if you like the demo but don't want to spend a ton of money then drop some cash on a basic membership, a universal gun, and some camo. Expect to spend about $30~40 dollars if you really like the experience and want to play a lot for a few months.TL;DR, if you want authentic hunting, this is it. Also much much much better with friends in multiplayer.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												Rarely do I review a game, but I feel in this instance I must.theHunter is the best hunting sim out there. This alone demands that a certain demographic -- those not looking for a hunting arcade shooter where animals pop up every ten seconds -- take notice.Yes, it costs for a yearly license to shoot every animal in the game. And yes, there are new free animals available for hunt, rotated every two weeks. My suggestion to a new hunter just starting out would be to find what animals are free, then go after them to see if you like the game enough to pay fora  license.And yes, weapons cost money, as do callers, clothes, and everything else in the game. This is a part of what makes it a great game, in my opinion. There's a sense of ownership and challenge when you purchase a new weapon and bring it out into the field. Leveling up a weapon is actually fun when you know you've just paid for it. I've been in the game for years now and do not own every weapon in the game, nor do I need to: I've had a blast leveling up the ones I do have, and I am nowhere near to mastery with any save the pump shotgun.To trash this masterpiece because of its aggressive business model is a real shame. For my part, I am happy to continue to support the devs with my money because they're constantly adding new things.Bottom line: if you want a hunting sim, here's the best available to you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												Ever since they added the "Free Rotation" feature, a mechanic that switches the available to hunt without a license, the game has become much more fun for players who don't own a membership. After long turmoil, the developers are making the game better. I do want to note that to get other items THEY ARE NOT FREE. You still have to buy em$ and there's no way of earning it. Yet.Anyways, my review of the game is yes, it's a very patience demanding game. Walking on trails through the lush forests of the reserves takes a while, but with the right equipment you can radically change your experience. I normally use some kind of bow for hunting but I also bought a nice .308 rifle for longer ranges and bigger game, I.E. Moose or bear. The bows are permitted to hunt EVERYTHING. I see these reviews down here are mostly negative but they have changed the game so it can be more fun. Give it another chance. For a number rating of 1-10... I give it a 7/10 mostly for the very demanding proccesing power.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												The only hunting simulator worth playing out there at the moment!The Hunter couples gorgeous graphics and immersive sound design to create vast environments that feel real when you step into them, something that other hunting games out there just don’t replicate. Recent hunting games have been shoe-horning you down corridors while Ibex and Lions jump out onto your shotgun barrel. The Hunter gives you the opportunity to experience the journey, a complete hunting scenario: Listening out for calls, tracking, and observation, not just constantly providing a slurry of beautiful beasts to bludgeon.I believe the game suffers when informing new comers. I’d recommend checking out the wiki before jumping in as there are some rules for Guest players who haven’t purchased a membership regarding what you can hunt and where. I have all confidence in the Dev team though! They are constantly active and seem to value and utilise feedback. New content is always on the horizon whether it is new gear, weapons, species or reserves to hunt. The game also boasts a strong community to hunt alongside or against in an interesting array of hunting challenges.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												theHunter is one of the most enjoyable and most beautiful hunting games available at this time IMO of course. The realistic aspect is not to far extreme where you find yourself waiting a whole day to bag and tag a single animal, but at the same time not at all arcade-y where you can gun down 5 deer in a matter of seconds. The pace of this game is rather rewarding is the sense of accomplishment when it come to the hunt.The main complaint that many have is there price structure. Yes, it can get expensive purchasing all that is available for this game. In fact If I recall correctly that if you happen to buy everything all at once (not including consumables and a ammo), you are looking at about a $600 price tag.  Yes, a lot of money, but at the same time compare that to Train Simulator 2015 which holds a price tag well over double of theHunter for all of its DLC. This game should not be considered Free-To-Play, but rather Free-To-Test or simple know it as a Demo since you are only allowed to hunt 1 species of deer (Mule Deer) on 1 reserve (Loggers Point). Also some have stated this is a Pay-To-Win game. Far from it IMO. Buying the ingame equipment and such doesnt make you a better hunter than everyone else. You just have more options to hunt and hunt with. Purchasing items in this game is like buying DLC for any other game in the long run. You do get to keep them forever minus consumables, but those can even be purchased with the ingame currency, gm$ which are earned buy completing ingame missions.At this current time, theHunter is being offered on the Steam Holiday Sale (2014) for 20% off on bundles.  If you have any  form of interest and are willing to support a game that actually works vs. the latest and greatest AAA titles that havent been, now would be a great time to purchase. The largest bundle is currently going for 39.99.  This includes an annual membership that alone cost 35 dollars during the normal time of the year, but also included in this bundle is $85 worth of gear that will allow you to hunt everything and anything under the sun within this game.  Even when the sale lets up, a price tag of 49.99 is not bad. $35 for the annual and $15  for the additional $85 worth of gear.All and all, I recommend this game to those that enjoy a good hunt and are will to invest a little money (the bundle) into it as you would any other game title that isnt listed as Free-To-Play. After all... games dont make themselves.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												Ok, I don't write reviews very often but I felt the need to on this game.I was skeptical about theHunter at first due to the overwhelming number of negative reviews on Steam. I weighed it out and thought "well, it's free", so I wasn't out anything by giving it a shot...and I'm glad I did.I like hunting. In real life, I love hunting. Unfortunately, I can only do so certain times in the year...and this game fills that void. This isn't a "game" in a traditional sense, it is practically a hunting simulator and it is done so well.The negative reviews all come from people who hate micro-transactions and expect completely free things. The game itself is free. You can hunt whitetail deer, european rabbits, and pheasant any time, along with two other animals which are selected/rotate on a weekly basis. Right now it's black bear and bison I think. If you like the free stuff, you can pay for the game by buying a membership, or different guns, or licenses...whatever floats your boat. I personally bought the Trailrunner membership for $49.99 because I like hunting and this game is well made. I normally spend $50 or so on any other game I play, I have absolutely no problem spending the same for something I truly enjoy. It nets me a year of hunting any animal, plus all sorts of other goodies like weapons, outfits, treestands, etc. To summarize: This is not a game for just anyone, and it's definitely not fast-paced. It's hunting. But it doesn't deserve negative reviews based solely on how the developers have chosen to take their profit from it. The game is free. The REAL game is going to cost you a bit if you so choose.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												Rarely do I review a game, but I feel in this instance I must.theHunter is the best hunting sim out there. This alone demands that a certain demographic -- those not looking for a hunting arcade shooter where animals pop up every ten seconds -- take notice.Yes, it costs for a yearly license to shoot every animal in the game. And yes, there are new free animals available for hunt, rotated every two weeks. My suggestion to a new hunter just starting out would be to find what animals are free, then go after them to see if you like the game enough to pay fora  license.And yes, weapons cost money, as do callers, clothes, and everything else in the game. This is a part of what makes it a great game, in my opinion. There's a sense of ownership and challenge when you purchase a new weapon and bring it out into the field. Leveling up a weapon is actually fun when you know you've just paid for it. I've been in the game for years now and do not own every weapon in the game, nor do I need to: I've had a blast leveling up the ones I do have, and I am nowhere near to mastery with any save the pump shotgun.To trash this masterpiece because of its aggressive business model is a real shame. For my part, I am happy to continue to support the devs with my money because they're constantly adding new things.Bottom line: if you want a hunting sim, here's the best available to you.

												Well I'm pretty sure I played this game before, the first map looked very familiar, which was very discouraging as the last time I saw no animals at all.This time I played the tutorials that weren't there before and they went well. Then I went off to try and hunt.Found a bunch of deer, yet every shot I took my gun lowered and I got a message saying I have no license.After a bit of investigating I found out all about the supposed licensing. The "free" part consists of 1 type of deer and a type of bird.Went and looked further and decided I'll try the $10US membership so I got all licenses.After that I went back and things went down hill. Spent quite a few hours playing and the more time went by the less animals I found. Some times I'd be following a track and suddenly the "huntermate" would turn me around or loop over the previously found track. Other time the track I was looking for wasn't actually in the direction I was pointed and other times it'd just go cold out of nowhere. Some "mate" that is.On the way back to the camp I see a turkey out of nowhere and so shoot it, to which I get told off for an "unpermitted hit" for using the wrong ammo. So I leave and go to the shop to find all the ammo costs more real money along with every other item.Going to uninstall this, and if I could I'd have my $10 back too.Steam should also remove the "free to play tag" since 99% isn't free.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												So, I'm back, and this time, an in-depth (not really) review of thehunter. So, yes I know, microtransactions suck, but even if you pay the $15.00 fee for a license(3 months, I believe), you WILL enjoy this game. I happen to find the game really fun. I have decided to buy the $50.00 membership (12 months). The $15.00 and both, the $50.00 plan, come with weapons. The $15.00 comes with a little bit of stuff, but not a load. The $50.00 gives you a bow, two pistols, two shotguns, and two rifles (I may be wrong about that). They both, of course give you a license to hunt all animals and unlimited basic ammo. So if you really don't like the idea of the game, then maybe this will help you face the microtransactions, if you want to play, of course. Thanks for reading this review, this is my opinion of the game, I enjoy playing it, and have collected this informaton since the last time I wrote a review on this game.

From current reviews, I have seen that there is a new Developer to replace the other, and now you have to spend at least $200 in order to feel like you have a full hunting experience. Truly, if this game became a bit less of a pain to begin playing, I would try to play this amazing looking game myself.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												WHAT IS THE HUNTER?The hunter is a simulation game based on real life hunting, it requires patience and it's time consuming but rewarding in the end. there is something about that feeling of stalking your pray knowing that one simple sound may spooke the price buck, but if your quiet and careful a well place shot to a vital organ may kill it instantly and you go home with a trophy or you can miss and track him back again all depends how you aproach the sitation.The world is expansive, lot of walking but fear not aoutowalk option is availive!!, there are a big number of different variaty of animals from a simple mule deer to white tail,brown bears,moose,canadian goose among many others, not to mention weapons like hunting rifles (of course), bows, shotguns, revolvers, special rifles, as well as clothing and hunting tools. truly in an immersice world with a lot in your hands to choose and make your simulation a better experience.IS IT FREE TO PLAY OR PAY TO WIN?The game is free to play with its restrictions, currently you can can hunt two animals for free, mule deers and rabbits (male & female), you can roam and explore any map but the animals are restiricted to a membership or hunting permit found at this link.http://www.thehunter.com/#bank/membershipsplease read carefully the perks of each memberships and permits before proceeding to purchase. Ladies and genteleman it is important to consider the efforert of the developers and the fact that they need to gain something out of this,j ust as if you would invent something would you give it fully for free??...the answer is no! lets not be naive nor insult our inteligence, if you like this game support the developers. they are not forcing you to buy it it's all up to you., you want to spend 10 dollars or euros or 50 or more it's up tp you, in the end you make your experience, you decide what to buy. if you dont like the game dont ruin the experience for others just because you dont like the transaction system, act as you would like others to act towards you and put yourself in the developers and creators shoes before saying anything.IS IT WORTH INCESTING IN THE GAME OR PLAYING IT?yes!, if you agree, like this kind of games and can most importantly run this game then it's worth it, but i suggest you give it a try first, play it a couple of days and see if you dont get bored with the basic free membership, if you then really like it and want to expand your hunting experience, please support the developers and most importantly enjoy the game.Thanks everyone for taking the time to read this review i hope this helps in making a better hunter out of you, see you on the reserves lol.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												-Free to play no, very restricted demo yes. On the Loggers Point reserve you can hunt mule deer and rabbits but only get a gun for the rabbits.-Pay to win no, typical subscription game yes, and at around $3.33 a month and continuous updates I see this as a great value.-Extra equipment too costly no, able to purchase a whole crap tonne of mini expansions yes. When I first started I bought the entry level bundle for $15 and $10 worth of in game money. I got exactly what I wanted to hunt with for $5 less than the medium bundle. It's not like you go to your sporting goods store and buy all their equipment and guns, the same goes here. I almost feel like buying equipment in this game is like buying tabletop wargaming minis. You end up choosy and the choices have meaningful merit.-The Havok engine is outstanding in 3d (fallout, Skyrim etc). Where most games can hinder you playing in 3d I have a hard time playing this without using it.The wiki, be sure to look up permitted ammo typeshttp://www.thehunterwiki.com/index.php?title=Main_PageThe.de one which seems more focused on mechanics (you may need to translate the page)http://de.thehunterwiki.com/index.php?title=Hauptseite

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Although you do need to invest some money to get the most enjoyment out of this game as you can, it is definitely worth it. As an avid hunter for over ten years now, I never thought I would find a video game that could come close to what the great outdoors are like. With each and every update, TheHunter inches closer and closer to this mark - actually it hit that mark a long time ago and just gets closer towards absolute perfection.The only thing a person really needs to buy is a weapon, or two, or ten...or thirty. Just so you have the ability to hunt every animal, you need compatible weapons. If you do missions and grind a bit, you can do this completely Free to Play - but it can be discouraging and seeing a large or trophy animal (or even a rare variant) appear before you and knowing you cannot take that trophy due to license restrictions would be disheartening - so really the only money anyone should spend would be on a subscription (which for a year is well-priced in my opinion, especially if you do the Trailblazer pack that comes with plenty of weapons and camouflage).At this point it just becomes a game you paid once for and it's like you're buying DLC if you really like it. You have the weapons and gear permanently, and if you play that year you purchased you should have enough GM$ to renew licenses and ammunition.On top of everything, it's MULTIPLAYER. Single lobbies do exist, but being able to hunt with a friend and scout together or compete for the largest trophy, it's just loads of fun. Even counting down from 3-1 so you both can take down trophies simultanaeously...it's just great overall.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												I actually really like this game, I play it with friends and we play it a lot. For all the people out there that complain about the game being too expensive, the f2p side of the game is basically a demo to see if you enjoy the game. If you like it, you can buy the 15$ membership which gives you all the basic essentials needed to play the game. The game needs money to survive and become more developed, it's not like the game could be successful if no one bought anything and everything was free. I think the 15$ is well worth, considering you can hunt everything and they give you everything you need to hunt everything. But, thats just my opinion. Well developed and updated game, 9.5/10 Scary as ♥♥♥♥ when charged by a bear.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												I personaly think that this is an exelent game.  Ok, you can't run around hoping you'll find something too shoot at, but that isn't hunting.  You have to walk to a spot, lure the animal too you wait untill you can get a good shot and then shoot.  Or you can follow the tracks of animals and shoot them that way. So if you are looking for a quick action shooter, keep looking, this requeres patience.  And yes you do need a licence for a lot off stuf, but i personaly think you can have fun with the things you can hunt without a licence.  And yes you need real money to get good equipment, but I walked with the basic gear around for an hour and i already got 3 confirmed kills, and 2 other animals that i've hit, but not killed.  So over all i think its worth playing

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												If you're happy blissfully walking about in a medium, well done graphics environment, and plan on hunting only the basic 3 (+2) animals (+2 seem to be on a weekly rotation, i.e. this week Turkey and Red Deer? are free), then definitely give it a go.The paid hunting licenses aren't that distasteful really as the base game is free.  The whole game is "stalk and shoot and claim", in its base form.  Doesn't matter what animal you're hunting, the basic gameplay seems the same.The rest of the paid gear and equipment appear to only make the end results happen quicker.  Having to buy ammunition for any bought weapons is a shame; although, for the base weapons, the ammunition is unlimited.It'll pass many hours if this is your thing, for free; if you get bored, some small cost purchases and you have weapons for life, and temporary licenses to keep it interesting.Free: 10/10Paid: 7/10 (because of continued license renewals, equipment depletion, and non-standard ammo purchases)

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												I find this game to be very enjoyable. It's quite a realistic experience, has a wide variety of firearms and bows to choose from, quite a number of different animals you can hunt, and seems they are adding weapons/animals regularly. Now if you play this for free, without spending money, you will at best be able to unlock only 2 firearms; the .243 single shot that you start with, then a less-than-prestine single shot shotgun which I call 'trusty rusty' because although it's in rough shape, I still find it to be effective enough for hunting. In fact with a shotgun, you can hunt literally any animal provided you have the license to do so and you use the proper ammo (bird shot/buck shot/slug). Also, if you don't spend money, you can only hunt mule deer starting out, then if you do enough missions and get about 6300 gm$, then you can buy the shotgun which will allow you to hunt rabbits as well because you can't do so with .243. From there, continue doing missions, and if you collect enough gm$, you can buy a license to hunt another animal.To put it simply; if you don't spend money, you will only be able to use up to 2 firearms, and it will be VERY labour intensive and time consuming to earn your way up to hunting anything but mule deer or cottontail rabbits. If you do EXCEEDINGLY well in competition hunts, you will be able to earn em$ which otherwise you can only buy with real money. It is THIS money that the vast majority of firearms/bows need in order to be bought, along with callers and camouflage. Personally, I've spent about $40 on the game, and I'm glad I did. I have a $15 3 month membership which allows me to hunt anything, it also gave me a pump action shotgun as well as a .357 Magnum, and the em$ I bought with the remaining $25 or so allowed me to buy a cap and ball muzzle loader, Kar98k, .22lr pistol, longbow, a couple callers, and some good camouflage that makes it harder for animals to see me in the majority of maps. Speaking of which, the maps are huge, with a variety of game to hunt in each one.This isn't a game in which you run around until you see something, then shoot it. Running will make you easy to be spotted, and will thus cause any game that sees you to scarper. There's also the issue of scent, so it pays to mind which direction the wind is going if you're getting really up close to an animal. As with real life, hunting requires patience, it requires accuracy, and it requires tracking (especially if you don't line the shot up right, simply wound the animal, and it runs off while bleeding). If you're looking for a run and gun game, look elsewhere. If you're looking for a hunting simulator, I don't think you'd be able to find a better one than this. This game also has bullet drop so mind your shots if they're 150-200m+, and also it keeps track of the weight of your loadout so it's not like you'll be heading out with 3 rifles, 30 rounds each, every caller you have, along with all the other equipment available to you lolRealism is a big deal in this game, and if that's your thing, as it has been mine for years, then you'll enjoy this thoroughly. Just keep the restrictions in mind unless you're cool with spending a few dollars. For less than $20 though, you get 3 months to hunt anything, along with a pump action shotgun which is all you really NEED to hunt literally everything (Though there are better options out there for long distance shots), and a .357 Magnum revolver which you can hunt red fox, coyote, mule deer, white tail deer, black tail deer, and I think Alpine Ibex (Basically mountain goes) as well as turkeys with. I gotta say, it's kinda fun to sneak through the woods, listening for calls, stalking up on animals as you track them, feeling your heart begin to race as you catch sight of your game, perhaps use a call to try and get it closer, line up that perfect shot, and watch as it either goes down in one hit, or hopefully just runs for a few seconds before collapsing. It's quite an intense experience, and when it goes well, gives you a satisfying feeling of accomplishment.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
AN HONEST REVIEW (expand for tl;dr)It's the first hunting game I like and have gotten into. You can hunt deer, rabbit, BEAR, and you actually have to live the life by sitting and waiting, it's the real deal. They even have setups to hunt duck, they have tents and calls along with GPS. It's the only decent hunting game I've played on steam, and everyone's whining about the business model. Look, In games like WoW you pay $15 a month just to be able to play. In this, you pay basically that for three whole months, not just one. Not to mention, you don't really have to pay. You can earn credit in-game to get a license. Everyone's complaining about the licenses as if they want every little thing to be freely fed to them. Wake-up call: Nothing in life is free. There are too many negative reviews based on people's opinion on the fact that you can't immediately hunt everything for free, and not nearly enough points about any actual problem with the game itself. How do you expect them to develop a game if everything is free? So it seems the game's rating has been tarnished by buttmad kids whining about licenses, some reviews are probably even jokes. It's a free game, just try it for yourself, see if you like how it plays, and progress. I promise the fee for a license isn't going to kill you, you spend more than that on breakfast everyday probably. Sorry for the rant, here's a TL;DRGoodVarious animals to hunt, with variations in guns and ammo to useMultiple maps to walk through, not restricted to only ever one areaSocial aspects (taking trophy shots, hunting in a party, competing)Updates now, and in the future giving us new animals, weapons, etcBadI had audio issues after killing some animals, high pitched screeches... *shudder*...Depending on who you hunt with, it can make or break your time spent.Micro-transactions**ok so yes, I'm ok with the whole license thing, you need to work for a license to get better animals to get more points and so on, but there are so many transactions for stuff like weapons, tents, clothing and calls and so on... But it IS their business model and how they make money, and it's a free game that actually works in the first place so. I'm willing to overlook it really, considering most of it is extra or you could earn enough to get what you need anyway. I hope we get more forgiving and sensible players in the future to balance out the mostly negative review it currently stands with, because I honestly don't think it deserves that despite anything bad I have to say about this game.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												After playing this game alot, i have decided to make a true review of this game. At the time of writing this, i have played a total of 489 hours (this game wasnt always on steam, so i have played it before it were), so my word can be trusted.To start things off, this game, theHunter, is aimed to be a hunting simulator. Although there are a few arcade-like functions, this game is mostly what it aims to be. Some people call this a "Pay-to-Win" game, but i will tell why it is not in a few seconds (or minutes, depending on your reading speed). This game offers alot of variety to paid users. If you buy, lets say, the Trailrunner membership (often best for thoose who are new and needs a great start), contains alot of usefull items. It gives you a few very usefull weapons, one camo set wich is very good against deer, license to hunt all species (there are many) for a year, diverce items and equipment. The weapons you recieve is mostly made up of: .300 Bolt Action rifle, .270 Bolt Action rifle, Compound Bow "Snakebite" (most powerfull compound bow, although not most powerfull bow after all) and the .30-06 Lever Action rifle. Theese are not all weapons, but they allow you to hunt almost all species in all the reserves. This game offers alot of different ways to track, spot, stalk and kill prey. You can use lures to attract most species to get them closer to you so you can kill them with a bow, a shotgun, a pistol, or you can use the .300 with a 3-9x scope to pick them off at range. A wide variety of weapons are available to be purchased ranging from a .22LR air rifle to take down small bird and rabbits, to the 9.3x62mm Anschütz rifle and shotguns using slug ammunition to take down the biggest of bear and moose. To buy theese weapons, you need an in-game currency called em$. This currency can be gained in a number of ways: Purchasing it for real money and earning it from competitions and certain offers. The easiest way is to purchase. You can also purchase tents to spawn in, treestands/blinds/tripods to sit in to take down prey without it noticing you, and other different tools that may aid you during hunts. Free users only start with the .243 Bolt Action rifle. A weak weapon, but still capable of taking down the most basic free-to-play animal: the Mule Deer. Although Mule Deer is not the only free-to-play animal, it is the only one you may take down using the .243 rifle. There are a huge number off different species, all with their own unique behaviour and pelt characteristics. This game cannot be a "Pay-to-Win" game, as there is no real true goal. Its like a open world sandbox, although with the characteristics of hunting. This game can never be completed fully, wich is why you can never win. I will not keep writing this huge text so much more, as this would take alot of time.Pros:-Fun and interesting gameplay.-Get to have a slight feel to hunt animals.-Feeling the adrenaline rush when you spot that Roe Buck with thoose huge antlers.-Many different gameplay mechanics to track, spot, stalk and kill your prey.-Fairly realistic.-Free to play.Cons:-Fairly expensive if you want to get the most out of the game, although not as expensive as titles like World of Warcraft.-Still a few interesting (although harmless) bugs and glitches.-Animal behaviour could be better.-Ballistics could be better.-Weapon mechanics could be better.-In-game skills is very, VERY, time consuming to level up.Conclusion: A great game that i would recomment people to try out. Start as a free-to-play, and if you feel this game is for you, get a membership. Get serious in playing. This game is not for everyone, so i cannot promise any user to be satisfied. I am personally in love with this game, and have inspired me to enter high school with a education line in "Hunting & Wildlife Preservation". Devs are also happy to assist on their social networks. I cannot be more happy with this product, and i hope you will find this review of use. Also i cannot thank the devs behind this game enough, it has given me litteratly days of fun in total. Give the game a try, atleast it begins as free-to-play. Thanks to GunninGamerz for letting me post his beginner tutorial, you can watch it  here

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												I have played this game for a about 2 years now (almost exclusively outside steam). I have made good friends within the community and enjoyed thousands of hours in this game.General characteristics of the game:The Hunter is a game trying to find a balance between a realistic simulator and a fun game. It is not fast paced and it might take some time before you understand the mechanics of the game. You can play in any way you want; some people focus on winning competitions or getting on the general leaderboards, others enjoy luring in birds or just walking around in a reserve, tracking and calling for the animals they love to hunt. Downloading this game for free will give you very limited options, you will recieve a weapon that only allows you to hunt 1 species. However, if you are willing to pay for some licenses and gear, you can hunt all of the species you like and use the weapons you are fond of. The achievement system depends on the animals you shoot, and the weapons you use. Killing animals and using different weapons gives you HunterScore, which is the basis for your position on the leaderboards.If you wish to have all the weapons, it will cost you a lot of money. However there are some great bundles that give you good weapons and permission to hunt all species in the game. Buying licenses for specific species is something I would advise against. If you buy membership packs, you get permission to shoot all species for a certain time + some nice weapons and gear. Furthermore, this game has two types of current EM$ and GM$; the EM$ can only be bought with real money and allows you to buy everything in the store, the GM$ is earned by doing missions and special events, and can be used buy consumables that improve your game or a special shotgun. If you are thinking about buying things from the ingame store, don't hesitate to message me on steam, I can give you some advice on what to buy. Pros:- There are many different species (A-typical and rare colored animals can be found [albino, melanistic etc.] )- There are many different weapons (incl. rifles, handguns, bows. Modern and old) - Very nice reserves- Good graphics- Many competitions in which you can compete with fellow hunters- It's challenging- It will keep you off the streets for years if you enjoy it- Frequent updates- Many special events (Holidays with special competitions and store discounts!)- Many great people in the community- A very active forum, where all your questions can be answeredCons:- It has bugs, it often takes a long time before they are fixed (Some of these have been around for a long time)- Server is down a few times every month for a few minutes to a few hours- It's expensive if you want to have a lot of gear- Very limited options for character customisationCheers, Gierenhart (Grafzerk in theHunter)

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Besides the fact that the game launcher doesnt allow you to purchase a membership from within the launcher itself (some or other error most people get - go onto their website and you can buy memberships, em$ etc), its a fun game to play - with friends!Sure, the single player hunts are rewarding, but there is nothing better than running around with a trusted friend while you try play pin the .300 on the bear!Also, and this nearly turned my review from a positive to a negative, when the launcher tells you that you need to update in order to play, never assume it will just be as easy as -close game-->press [play] in steam--> watch update. I have tried a few things, none have worked. Not sure if they are just slow to push their updates to steam after telling the launcher not to let anyone play, or if their launcher code is just not that well written.. who knows.. If you want a free-to-play game that you will need to spend between $30 and $50 to enjoy, then this is the game for you!If you are still reading, here are some pros and cons:PROS]- Its fun with friends ]- Ballistics work fairly ok]- Tracking animals is frustrating at times, but rewarding when you get the basics right]- Wide variety of game to hunt]- Visuals are beautiful!CONS]- Their business model is blatant. $5 will get you 500em$. In order to buy a tent (spawn point + inventory) you will need to buy 1000em$ as the tents start at 550em$. What can you do with the remaining 450em$? Not much worth mentioning. Maybe a lure or two. ]- The weapons do not have a "this is how far the gun potetially shoots" info section. Would help a little. ]- Bugs in the launcher]- No way to change the view distance. Its slightly annoying when you see something move, sight down the scope and see massive grass covering where the animal was. Personal issue: I run a Titan X, let me throw my view distance through the roof. The game runs between 140 and 190 fps with everything maxed (steady 120 - 138fps in heavy woodland and forest) , i wouldnt mind more visual rendering options to make better use of my hardware.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												Bottomline Upfront:  Its worth dropping some coin to get a membership starter pack.  This is the game for you if enjoy first person shooters, but need something laid back to play after work to unwind on, prior to going to bed and getting up early the next morning.  Absolutely gorgeous, runs on a wide range of machines.  Pacing is excellent for what it is.  The least arcadey of the hunting simulators, but certainly one of the most polished.  Note: If you do see my low hours, that's a bit deceptive... I've put many more hours on it prior to it going on Steam, and only recently crossed it into my Steam account.Lastly... for those that criticize the game for being deceptively marketed as "free-to-play", I say "nuts!"  If you're going to be critical towards a single game, you're going after the wrong target.  The whole industry should move away from the term "free to play" because nothing is free... to include the player's time as well as the player's private information.  Free-to-play these days is too often synonymous with getting a fully loaded game that you & the developer are expecting the die-hards to drop enough cash to cover the expense of making and maintaining it.  Nothing wrong with that... that's a viable model for many games, but that is not "free" either.  Let's be clear.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												I have played this game for a about 2 years now (almost exclusively outside steam). I have made good friends within the community and enjoyed thousands of hours in this game.General characteristics of the game:The Hunter is a game trying to find a balance between a realistic simulator and a fun game. It is not fast paced and it might take some time before you understand the mechanics of the game. You can play in any way you want; some people focus on winning competitions or getting on the general leaderboards, others enjoy luring in birds or just walking around in a reserve, tracking and calling for the animals they love to hunt. Downloading this game for free will give you very limited options, you will recieve a weapon that only allows you to hunt 1 species. However, if you are willing to pay for some licenses and gear, you can hunt all of the species you like and use the weapons you are fond of. The achievement system depends on the animals you shoot, and the weapons you use. Killing animals and using different weapons gives you HunterScore, which is the basis for your position on the leaderboards.If you wish to have all the weapons, it will cost you a lot of money. However there are some great bundles that give you good weapons and permission to hunt all species in the game. Buying licenses for specific species is something I would advise against. If you buy membership packs, you get permission to shoot all species for a certain time + some nice weapons and gear. Furthermore, this game has two types of current EM$ and GM$; the EM$ can only be bought with real money and allows you to buy everything in the store, the GM$ is earned by doing missions and special events, and can be used buy consumables that improve your game or a special shotgun. If you are thinking about buying things from the ingame store, don't hesitate to message me on steam, I can give you some advice on what to buy. Pros:- There are many different species (A-typical and rare colored animals can be found [albino, melanistic etc.] )- There are many different weapons (incl. rifles, handguns, bows. Modern and old) - Very nice reserves- Good graphics- Many competitions in which you can compete with fellow hunters- It's challenging- It will keep you off the streets for years if you enjoy it- Frequent updates- Many special events (Holidays with special competitions and store discounts!)- Many great people in the community- A very active forum, where all your questions can be answeredCons:- It has bugs, it often takes a long time before they are fixed (Some of these have been around for a long time)- Server is down a few times every month for a few minutes to a few hours- It's expensive if you want to have a lot of gear- Very limited options for character customisationCheers, Gierenhart (Grafzerk in theHunter)

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												*Please give this a read* So, I had just taken a peek at the reviews for this game to see if others had been enjoying it as much as I have, and I was shocked with all the negatives there were. A lot of the negative responses I saw were complaints on the fact that the game itself isn't really free to play or that it's pay to win. But you're playing the full game, you're just limited to what you can hunt, which is Mule Deer. Now, that doesn't sound like a whole lot, and it really isn't in comparison to what else the game has to offer. But I spent a solid 3 hours straight tracking and hunting mule deer and having a blast. I quickly realized that this game was well worth shelling out some money for. The terrain is gorgeous, the way all of the animals behave is very realistic, the tracking keeps me very interested in the hunt and the overall experience is just amazing. To those of you who were looking for a free hunting game with lots of guns and animals to shoot, I'm sorry to disappoint you, but this isn't it. The free part is just a demo really of the full game where you can hunt mule deer and get that taste.  But if you're looking for a great hunting game and are willing to drop 30-40 bucks on a bundle that gives you 12 months of unlimited hunting, a 12 gauge shotgun(comes with all different types of shot to hunt everything), a new stronger rifle with a new scope, a .44 and .357 revolver, some better camo'd clothes, some calls and a few other goodies, then this is definitely the game for you. Seriously, if you enjoy the experience of just hunting the mule deer for a bit, drop some money into it and go for the full experience, it's really worth it. This game deserves to be paid for.9/10 (Only because of microtransactions with all the rest of the items that don't come in a bundle, but none of that other stuff is actual stuff that's needed to enjoy the game and have the full experience)

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Otherwise known as the patience simulator, this open world hunting game is all other kinds of beauty. It has its bad points and good points, mostly good, but I think it's definitely a one-of-a-kind. At first, it is a free-to-play game, but the options are scarce, and what you can do vastly outweighs the actual point of playing. They give you the ability to kill mule deer (males are hard to come by) and cottontail rabbits (which you can't even kill due to the caliber of the gun you are given to begin with. I upgraded to the "Wayfarer" membership and was rewarded with a shotgun (complete with basic ammo) and a revolver, both very useful weapons as now I can practically hunt anything that I want to.The gun sounds and mechanics are beefy and feel realistic, the tracking is awesome and finally getting a kill is quite rewarding. The animals behaviours are quite accurate also, being an individual who is thoroughly intrigued by animal behaviour, I definitely felt aware of their naturalistic tendencies.Overall, if you're looking to play a game that you have to invest a little bit of cash in to play properly, then go ahead. You won't find anything like this anywhere else.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Besides the fact that the game launcher doesnt allow you to purchase a membership from within the launcher itself (some or other error most people get - go onto their website and you can buy memberships, em$ etc), its a fun game to play - with friends!Sure, the single player hunts are rewarding, but there is nothing better than running around with a trusted friend while you try play pin the .300 on the bear!Also, and this nearly turned my review from a positive to a negative, when the launcher tells you that you need to update in order to play, never assume it will just be as easy as -close game-->press [play] in steam--> watch update. I have tried a few things, none have worked. Not sure if they are just slow to push their updates to steam after telling the launcher not to let anyone play, or if their launcher code is just not that well written.. who knows.. If you want a free-to-play game that you will need to spend between $30 and $50 to enjoy, then this is the game for you!If you are still reading, here are some pros and cons:PROS]- Its fun with friends ]- Ballistics work fairly ok]- Tracking animals is frustrating at times, but rewarding when you get the basics right]- Wide variety of game to hunt]- Visuals are beautiful!CONS]- Their business model is blatant. $5 will get you 500em$. In order to buy a tent (spawn point + inventory) you will need to buy 1000em$ as the tents start at 550em$. What can you do with the remaining 450em$? Not much worth mentioning. Maybe a lure or two. ]- The weapons do not have a "this is how far the gun potetially shoots" info section. Would help a little. ]- Bugs in the launcher]- No way to change the view distance. Its slightly annoying when you see something move, sight down the scope and see massive grass covering where the animal was. Personal issue: I run a Titan X, let me throw my view distance through the roof. The game runs between 140 and 190 fps with everything maxed (steady 120 - 138fps in heavy woodland and forest) , i wouldnt mind more visual rendering options to make better use of my hardware.

												This game is awesome and lots of fun with your friends. Part of the game is free to play...but the best way to experience theHunter is to get a membership pack like the (Trailrunner Starter Pack) because you'll get a lot of really good gear and a 1 year membership that will let you hunt every animal on every reserve in the game with unlimited ammo for all your weapons as long as your a member (but you always get free ammo for the .243 starter rifle even if your not a member). With the constant development and the massive amount of already available content in this game I would say that theHunter is one on the best buys on Steam, and it lets the player pick what they want and how much to spend or not to spend on the game. I hope this review gives anyone that's thinking of giving this game a shot the confidence to take the plunge, because it's really worth it...especially if you like hunting and the outdoors.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												After playing this game alot, i have decided to make a true review of this game. At the time of writing this, i have played a total of 489 hours (this game wasnt always on steam, so i have played it before it were), so my word can be trusted.To start things off, this game, theHunter, is aimed to be a hunting simulator. Although there are a few arcade-like functions, this game is mostly what it aims to be. Some people call this a "Pay-to-Win" game, but i will tell why it is not in a few seconds (or minutes, depending on your reading speed). This game offers alot of variety to paid users. If you buy, lets say, the Trailrunner membership (often best for thoose who are new and needs a great start), contains alot of usefull items. It gives you a few very usefull weapons, one camo set wich is very good against deer, license to hunt all species (there are many) for a year, diverce items and equipment. The weapons you recieve is mostly made up of: .300 Bolt Action rifle, .270 Bolt Action rifle, Compound Bow "Snakebite" (most powerfull compound bow, although not most powerfull bow after all) and the .30-06 Lever Action rifle. Theese are not all weapons, but they allow you to hunt almost all species in all the reserves. This game offers alot of different ways to track, spot, stalk and kill prey. You can use lures to attract most species to get them closer to you so you can kill them with a bow, a shotgun, a pistol, or you can use the .300 with a 3-9x scope to pick them off at range. A wide variety of weapons are available to be purchased ranging from a .22LR air rifle to take down small bird and rabbits, to the 9.3x62mm Anschütz rifle and shotguns using slug ammunition to take down the biggest of bear and moose. To buy theese weapons, you need an in-game currency called em$. This currency can be gained in a number of ways: Purchasing it for real money and earning it from competitions and certain offers. The easiest way is to purchase. You can also purchase tents to spawn in, treestands/blinds/tripods to sit in to take down prey without it noticing you, and other different tools that may aid you during hunts. Free users only start with the .243 Bolt Action rifle. A weak weapon, but still capable of taking down the most basic free-to-play animal: the Mule Deer. Although Mule Deer is not the only free-to-play animal, it is the only one you may take down using the .243 rifle. There are a huge number off different species, all with their own unique behaviour and pelt characteristics. This game cannot be a "Pay-to-Win" game, as there is no real true goal. Its like a open world sandbox, although with the characteristics of hunting. This game can never be completed fully, wich is why you can never win. I will not keep writing this huge text so much more, as this would take alot of time.Pros:-Fun and interesting gameplay.-Get to have a slight feel to hunt animals.-Feeling the adrenaline rush when you spot that Roe Buck with thoose huge antlers.-Many different gameplay mechanics to track, spot, stalk and kill your prey.-Fairly realistic.-Free to play.Cons:-Fairly expensive if you want to get the most out of the game, although not as expensive as titles like World of Warcraft.-Still a few interesting (although harmless) bugs and glitches.-Animal behaviour could be better.-Ballistics could be better.-Weapon mechanics could be better.-In-game skills is very, VERY, time consuming to level up.Conclusion: A great game that i would recomment people to try out. Start as a free-to-play, and if you feel this game is for you, get a membership. Get serious in playing. This game is not for everyone, so i cannot promise any user to be satisfied. I am personally in love with this game, and have inspired me to enter high school with a education line in "Hunting & Wildlife Preservation". Devs are also happy to assist on their social networks. I cannot be more happy with this product, and i hope you will find this review of use. Also i cannot thank the devs behind this game enough, it has given me litteratly days of fun in total. Give the game a try, atleast it begins as free-to-play. Thanks to GunninGamerz for letting me post his beginner tutorial, you can watch it  here

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												I have played this game for a about 2 years now (almost exclusively outside steam). I have made good friends within the community and enjoyed thousands of hours in this game.General characteristics of the game:The Hunter is a game trying to find a balance between a realistic simulator and a fun game. It is not fast paced and it might take some time before you understand the mechanics of the game. You can play in any way you want; some people focus on winning competitions or getting on the general leaderboards, others enjoy luring in birds or just walking around in a reserve, tracking and calling for the animals they love to hunt. Downloading this game for free will give you very limited options, you will recieve a weapon that only allows you to hunt 1 species. However, if you are willing to pay for some licenses and gear, you can hunt all of the species you like and use the weapons you are fond of. The achievement system depends on the animals you shoot, and the weapons you use. Killing animals and using different weapons gives you HunterScore, which is the basis for your position on the leaderboards.If you wish to have all the weapons, it will cost you a lot of money. However there are some great bundles that give you good weapons and permission to hunt all species in the game. Buying licenses for specific species is something I would advise against. If you buy membership packs, you get permission to shoot all species for a certain time + some nice weapons and gear. Furthermore, this game has two types of current EM$ and GM$; the EM$ can only be bought with real money and allows you to buy everything in the store, the GM$ is earned by doing missions and special events, and can be used buy consumables that improve your game or a special shotgun. If you are thinking about buying things from the ingame store, don't hesitate to message me on steam, I can give you some advice on what to buy. Pros:- There are many different species (A-typical and rare colored animals can be found [albino, melanistic etc.] )- There are many different weapons (incl. rifles, handguns, bows. Modern and old) - Very nice reserves- Good graphics- Many competitions in which you can compete with fellow hunters- It's challenging- It will keep you off the streets for years if you enjoy it- Frequent updates- Many special events (Holidays with special competitions and store discounts!)- Many great people in the community- A very active forum, where all your questions can be answeredCons:- It has bugs, it often takes a long time before they are fixed (Some of these have been around for a long time)- Server is down a few times every month for a few minutes to a few hours- It's expensive if you want to have a lot of gear- Very limited options for character customisationCheers, Gierenhart (Grafzerk in theHunter)
